Group sessions, usually lasting 30 minutes, take place once or twice a week for eight weeks. Between sessions, participants continue to do the exercises on their own as recommended, usually at home. This allows people with busy schedules to improve their health on their own schedule, in their own home or other convenient location such as a park or senior center. Tai Chi Easy is adapted to make the movements easy for people of any ability or disability, since the adaptations can be done quickly. Tai Chi Easy reduces many of the complexities and difficulties of "traditional" Tai Chi through a series of simple adaptations to overcome the challenges of balance, flexibility, and coordination that arise from a sedentary lifestyle. It is also designed to overcome many of the cultural barriers that prevent individuals from attempting Tai Chi by using accessible techniques that can be done seated or standing. Tai Chi Easy includes instruction in a gentle form that can be performed seated in a chair or standing with assistance. Simple breath work and guided relaxation techniques will also be taught. Tai Chi Easy enables its practitioners - regardless of age or physical ability to experience many of the health benefits of Tai Chi. The primary benefits are stress reduction and improved health, especially for pain relief and improved joint and bone health. It teaches participants to use their own body weight to provide gentle resistance for muscle building and increased circulation while at the same time teaching them a form of deep meditation. The adaptations can be found on my website. http://www.taihealth.com/tai-ch easy.htm. The goal is to create strong and vital people so that chronic pain can be managed or relieved. model_response: The study arm is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multi-center, two disease cohort trial which will evaluate the safety and efficacy of the combination of Cemiplimab plus Ziv-Aflibercept in patients with metastatic uveal melanoma. The study will enroll approximately 250 subjects who will be randomized 1:1 to either Cemiplimab plus Aflibercept or placebo plus Aflibercept. The study is projected to enroll approximately 30 subjects in the safety run-in. All subjects will be treated with aflibercept for at least 8 weeks then re-randomized to either Cemiplimab or placebo and treated for 8 weeks. The primary efficacy endpoint to support marketing approval of this combination of Cemiplimab plus Ziv-Aflibercept will be the evaluation of progression-free survival (PFS). Secondary efficacy endpoints include assessments of objective response rate, duration of response, time to progression, disease control rate and other assays of clinical benefit based on radiographic assessment: RECIST, Chiron Genomics PET PD-L1 expression evaluation, or other clinical judgment. The primary safety endpoint will be a negative product-related safety laboratory event.  Additional safety and pharmacokinetic endpoints will be assessed to support safety assessment of this combined administration of Cemiplimab and Ziv-Aflibercept.

This specific design was chosen to maximize the treatment effect while minimizing the risk of significant side effects. By administering these two agents together in combination, we can increase the likelihood of anti-tumor activity while mitigating the risk of potential side effects on normal organs/tissues.

Yes, one more thing to note is that the study will primarily enroll participants with advanced or metastatic uveal melanoma, refractory to anti-PD-1 therapy.  The goal of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the combination of Cemiplimab and Ziv-Aflibercept in participants with this type of cancer. To date, the combination therapy has been found to be generally well tolerated, with evidence of disease stabilization or tumor shrinkage in some participants.

The treatment arm is called the experimental arm, which includes Cemiplimab and Ziv-aflibercept, both administered intravenously every 3 weeks. The control arm includes Ziv-Aflibercept alone, also administered IV every 3 weeks.

Assessing the feasibility of a clinical trial or study is an essential part of the protocol planning process. There are certain key considerations that should be addressed to determine a trial's feasibility and whether it is practical to conduct. Some questions that can help determine feasibility are: Is it possible researchers and participants have what they need to conduct the trial? Is the number of participants that may be needed achievable? Is a valid study drug and intervention available? Is the protocol dose and duration manageable for the participants? Are ethical guidelines and safety measures in place? Is budget and staffing feasible? Can equipment be acquired and maintained? Answering these questions can help assess feasibility, and trial modifications can be made if necessary. In your case, using an online meeting platform such as Zoom ® seems feasible, and you can talk to people who have participated to assess its effectiveness. Study Rationale
The aim of this study is to evaluate the outcomes of a tracheostomy management protocol implemented within a Swiss paraplegic center.
The study protocol includes three arms. The first arm will consist of a cohort of patients that receive usual care. A second arm will include a cohort of patients who will undergo the intervention of interest: a decannulation management protocol. The last arm will consist of a cohort of patients whose tracheostomies will be decannulated by the aforementioned protocol. The main outcome measures of interest are hospitalization times, complication rates, and quality of life measurements.
The study population will consist of all adult patients who require a prolonged tracheostomy at a Swiss paraplegic center.
The time period for enrollment for the current study is set to commence in January 2020 and will end no later than December 2023.
This trial is funded by the Swiss National Science Foundation. The sample size has not yet been determined.
The present study has not yet been published, and no publications have been authored by the investigators.
Anyone with significant interest in the study is encouraged to participate in a consultation meeting for the study protocol. No formal approval from an institutional review board is required at present.
Considering the specific context and circumstances of the research question, there are no known risks associated with participation.
There is no plan to publish or distribute any study results at present.

model_response: The number of arms in the trial should probably be 2, 3, or 6, in order to have adequate power, along with the control group. You'll want to make sure that no other interventions are administered during or after the intervention phase (these would go into the confounding factors). You might want to use a washout period and/or a screening period before and/or after, in order to make sure that the intervention group is comparable to the control group before being subjected to the intervention. There are several blinding methods which could be employed, but if it's a surgical trial, I would highly recommend blinding both the subject and investigator. Any data collected before the intervention phase should be properly managed to avoid confounding factors. This usually takes the form of a prospective case register, or a core-lab. During the intervention phase, please make sure subjects are kept in groups, and try to reduce extrinsic variables as much as possible (don't have them wear different colors, don't have one nurse administer treatments, etc). Your study design should include a washout period and/or a followup period for sustainment of effect. Any serious unforeseen complications should have a plan in place to address them, and followup data should be collected for adverse effects. Certainly. The interventions in each arm will be the same, except for the transcortical surface texture. Those in the experimental arm will have Rex implants with a machined surface, whereas those in the comparator arm will have Rex implants with a rough surface. The machined surface will help us assess the clinical and radiographic outcomes of osseointegration with a machined transcortical portion. The rough surface will serve as a comparison to the machined surface, evaluating the outcomes of the same implant with a different surface texture.

The machined surface of the Rex implants has been shown to reduce microleakage and inflammation. However, rough surfaces have also been shown to promote better integration and osseointegration. Therefore, we want to compare the effectiveness of each surface in the same clinical scenario.

Certainly. The complete study arms will be as follows: Experimental arm 1: Rex transcortical implants with machined surface (active arm): • Implant placement will use the standard surgical protocol, including adequate bone removal, drilling of a straight line, the addition of collagen, and placement of the Rex implant with a machined surface. 2.5 mm bone taper for machined implants and 1.5 mm for roughened implants will be used, according to the brand's protocol. Random allocation to the two types of surfaces will be done for each implant. Active comparator arm 1: Rex transcortical implants with a roughened surface (passive arm): 2.5 mm will be placed according to the brand's protocol for roughened implants for all patients. Arm 2: Rex transcortical implants with machined surface (passive arm): the same insertion protocol and 2.5 mm bone taper will be used as the active arm. Random allocation to the two types of surfaces will be performed for each implant. The clinical and radiographic outcomes will be assessed.  Both control and experimental arms will be evaluated radiographically 3, 9, and 12 months after placement to check bone crest-to-implant ridge width and bone-to-implant osseointegration. Evaluation of clinical outcomes will be done with the following criteria for each patient: implant survival rate, peri-implant marginal bone loss, peri-implantitis, crest height, and plaque control. This protocol allows us to evaluate the clinical and radiological outcomes of rough versus machined implants for implant placement in narrow ridges with minimal bone. Additionally, it can help us understand the influence of surface roughness of implants in improving the clinical outcomes of implant therapy in this specific situation.  Interested individuals can contact me for the complete protocol. 
Adapting to local conditions is important. Some clinical situations require special attention and specific protocols to provide optimal outcomes. Using the appropriate design and surface of implants can optimize clinical and radiological results. We hope that this case example serves as a template and inspiration for similar studies in other clinical situations.

Atopic dermatitis, also known as eczema, is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin characterized by itching and inflammation. It is thought to be largely due to Type 2 immune dysregulation.1 Dupilumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds to and inhibits the activity of the Delta and Kappa subtypes of the IL-4 receptor on mast cells and some keratinocytes, resulting in decreased IgE and IgG type I cytokine responses. It is licensed for the treatment of moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis in adults and children 12 years of age or older who are not adequately treated with topical or corticosteroids. It is applied as a 300-mcg dose by subcutaneous injection every two weeks.

I'm glad you asked. Maitland mobilization technique includes passive manipulation of the tibia and gentle movement of the knee in a supine position to help increase synovial fluid in the knee. Interferential therapy increases blood flow and promoting healing in the affected area.

Interferential therapy involves the use of low-frequency, high-frequency, and anti-inflammatory currents alternating at 120 HZ for 20 minutes. This therapy will be applied to the patients in the experimental group.

Mulligan's mobilization technique involves high-velocity, low-amplitude manipulation of the joint through a range of motion in a gliding motion without resistance, and it is used for joints with decreased range of motion. Patients with joint pain, stiffness, or weakness are candidates for this technique. Parameters for myofascial release include frequency of treatment 2 Hz, pulse 900 microsec, and intensity until soreness disappears with no pain (patient-controlled).  What about the interferential therapy used in the comparator arm?

The following day, I received an email from another CRO asking my opinion on a clinical study design for a trial evaluating the safety and acceptability of a new cholesterol-lowering medication. Here's the text of the email:
Hi Clinical Trial Investigator,
Could you please briefly assess the attached clinical study design for a cholesterol-lowering trial? Our team includes an academic research organization, a medical communications agency, and a statistician. We would greatly appreciate your input for this important study at [TITLE OF STUDY].
The study's protocol involves a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover design with four weeks of treatment and twelve weeks of follow-up. The trial population consists of high-risk patients with LDL cholesterol levels between 130 and 180mg/dL. Subjects will receive either the treatment or a placebo for four weeks. After a two-week washout period, the other arm of treatment will be initiated. The primary endpoint is the change in LDL cholesterol at week 12, with additional assessments for secondary outcomes including total cholesterol, HDL, triglycerides, blood pressure, body weight, vital signs, and safety biomarkers. Hot compressing is a non-pharmacological treatment, and it is thought to increase blood circulation by inducing vasodilation, promoting neurovascular regeneration, and ameliorating nerve hypersensitivity. Cold compressing is thought to reduce pain and inflammation by vasoconstriction.

The application of hot compresses before chemotherapy has been shown to alleviate the symptoms of mild to moderate OCN in some patients. Warm temperature increase decreases the resistance in the blood vessels and nerve conduction speed, reduces vascular leakage around nerves and relieves symptoms of nerve entrapment.  By applying heat before chemotherapy, we can measure the effect of temperature on the occurrence and severity of neuropathy symptoms in this study.

In the cold compressing group, patients will receive cold compress interventions on their hands and feet. The temperature control will be maintained within the range of 12-18 degrees Celsius. By applying cold compresses before and after Oxaliplatin administration, the goal is to potentially alleviate peripheral neuropathy symptoms and improve the quality of life for patients undergoing chemotherapy. Monitoring for adverse reactions is crucial to ensure patient safety.

model_response: The intervention for the TNB Identity Affirmation Condition will involve the use of expressive writing in response to a vignette. The vignette will be developed with input from a clinical psychologist and focus on a common relatable situation that TNB individuals may experience, such as coming out as nonbinary. The goal of the intervention is to allow participants to reflect on and work through their feelings of internalized stigma and come away with a sense of affirmation and acceptance of their nonbinary identity.

For the IA + Strengthening Social Connection (SSC) Condition, participants will complete the same prompts as the IA condition, but will also write a letter of gratitude to someone who has provided support to the participant. This prompt is intended to promote connections and gratitude in addition to the affirmations of identity. The gratitude letter will provide the participant an opportunity for further processing and validation of support received.

As mentioned, the control arm will complete everyday writing prompts about events of the day. These prompts will not be TNB -focused, but instead will be general topics such as "what I ate for breakfast." The control condition is necessary to compare results against, as no intervention is expected to lead to a reduction in internalized stigma without some form of change in behavior or thought.

Thank you for using Chat Doctor. We're here to help with your medical questions.

Ask the client about the next step in the study protocol
Most likely, the next step will be trial design and endpoints. For more information on how to do that, refer to the article on study design.
Review the patient information booklet
Once you're done planning the study arms, make sure the information they'll receive matches the plan. Run through it with a fine-tooth comb to make sure it's medically accurate and covers all the important aspects of each intervention and disease. You don't want to waste time and resources on a trial that has misleading materials. 
Create a consent form
It's good practice to have an independent research team create a consent form and obtain study consent. They'll take the patient through the entire study information, risks, and benefits. Remember, everyone in the research team should have knowledge of the trial and the interventions at a minimum, but preferably deep understanding of both. 
Submit for Institutional Review Board (IRB) approval
Before initiating any study, you need IRB approval. This is a group of physicians and non-physicians who ensure the trial is ethical and will not harm patients. Don't skip this stage. The IRB can and will say no, and it will set the study back if they do. Make sure your protocol, consent form, and all the processes are in order before you submit. 
Start patient screening and enrollment
Once the trial is ready to go, you're ready to start screening the candidates. Make sure to carefully review the inclusion/exclusion criteria. You don't want to waste time on someone who falls out of the study parameters. 
Obtain and review imaging / lab / other data throughout the trial
There will be plenty of data collected throughout the trial. Keep it organized so you can access it quickly when you need it. If you're using a CRO, they'll present you with specific reports they generate and recommendations. 
Conduct quality assurance / quality control (QA/QC) reviews of the data
Every study can always benefit from extra sets of eyes looking over the data to find errors and oddities. Depending on the size and complexity of the study, QA/QC may have full time roles throughout the study or just reviews at specific milestones.

model_response: The second arm, Group B, will be the control arm where patients will not receive any intervention. This group will serve as the control arm and help us understand the natural course of Smoke Inhalation Injury with respect to inflammation and lung injury.

For the study design, we'll conduct a double-blinded, randomized controlled trial. Subjects will be randomized 1:1 to the intervention or control arm using an online randomization program. Allocation will be stratified by pre-trial smoking status. Patients will be excluded if they have clinical contraindications to heparin therapy. Endpoints will be changes in the severity of smoke-induced inflammation as assessed by the bronchoconstrictor challenge test on day 21 of treatment. Primary analysis will be by an interim analysis of change from baseline in the bronchoconstrictor challenge score. The study hypothesis is that nebulized heparin will decrease smoke-induced inflammation, as assessed by bronchoconstrictor challenge testing, compared to the control arm. To test this hypothesis, we are targeting a sample size of 160 subjects per arm, for a total of 320 subjects total.

model_response: For the study arm, we can use rituximab, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone. This combination has been shown to be highly effective in the management of follicular lymphoma. Is there anything else you'd like to include in the intervention/treatment arm?

The second arm should be a control arm, with rituximab combined with chemotherapy. The same drugs mentioned above will be used in this arm. Please note that rituximab will be given as an intravenous infusion.

Eligible participants are those with either previously untreated or relapsed/refractory follicular lymphoma. The randomization will be stratified by central nervous system (CNS) involvement or not and risk category (low, intermediate, or high).

In the rituximab arm, participants will receive rituximab on Day 1 of each 21-day cycle as well as on day 5 of Days 8, 12, 16, and 19. The first four cycles consist of the standard CHOP regimen, including cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone. After the induction period, rituximab alone is given for two additional years until disease progression. All participants are monitored for adverse events during the 300-day study period.
The third arm should involve a placebo plus chemotherapy arm.
Participants with follicular lymphoma who are treatment-naive or have relapsed and who have not previously received treatment with rituximab are eligible for this arm.
Participants in this arm will receive IVOD in combination with cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone (CHOP), or cyclophosphamide, vincristine, and doxorubicin (CVP) regimen.

For the fourth arm, we can consider the comparison against the standard of care. This arm will be of great interest to physicians and treatment decision makers, and the results will provide valuable information for healthcare systems and the health technology assessment.

Participants in this arm will receive odronextrexamab in combination with chemotherapy followed by observation or follow-up. The goal is to evaluate the impact of maintenance therapy in follicular lymphoma patients.
In this final arm, participants will receive odronextamab in combination with either cyclophosphamide, vincristine, and prednisone (CHOP regimen) or cyclophosphamide and vincristine (CVP regimen).

Study design Considerations by Population
The population you are including to participain the study, or your target population, may be broadly divided into 4 different groups:
Healthy, asymptomatic people who could be the usual care or control group, or the population that is targeted for an intervention
Patients selected to avoid exclusion and are under some treatment or therapy for a particular disease
Healthy volunteers who are treated as control in a placebo controlled study
People who are usually sick who are included in an observational study (the usual care group may also be included in this along with the ones receiving other treatment/or not receiving any).
Please note that the last group may also include a population under observation. For example, all subjects who are being considered for liver transplant.
In a randomised controlled trial(RCT), the target population to be randomised is the group that receives the treatment as well as its control.
The target population to be randomised in a crossover study usually consists of only that group which gets to receive the new treatment first.
For a cohort study, the target population is the entire group/people in which the incidence or prevalence (frequency) of an event has to be estimated.
For a case-control study, the target population could be all people who are diagnosed to have a disease and also the population at risk (i.e. free from disease).

Before defining the inclusion and exclusion criteria, it is helpful to have an understanding of what criteria to include or exclude in the final study product. This helps ensure the study is designed to provide the most relevant data for the intended goal of the study.
Below is an example of inclusion and exclusion criteria.
• Patients who are able and willing to provide valid informed consent
• Female or male patients age 18-80
• Patients with a score of 4 or less on the Modified Oxford Score for Humeral Fracture Severity
• Patients with a lengthy acute fracture
• Patients with a spiral and/or oblique fracture or minimal displacement fracture
• Patients who have had open or complex surgery in the last six months
Here in this instance, a screening tool like the Modified Oxford Score can be used to assist in identifying whether the fracture may be severe enough and will require the intervention. Remember, keeping the inclusion and exclusion criteria as narrow as possible will decrease the risk of type I errors but can increase the risk of type II errors.
A recent systematic review by Ramsay and colleagues  evaluated the use of noncompliance of randomized controlled trials with their pre-specified inclusion and exclusion criteria. This systematic review found that 80% of trials have at least 1 significant protocol violation. It is difficult for a researcher to be completely cognizant of all criteria that may be violated during the course of a trial, especially when assessing safety and efficacy of a treatment. Therefore, the authors strongly suggest obtaining independent review of trial protocols before enrolling participants.

How to Determine the Sample Size for Your Clinical Trial Steps 1) Define the key outcomes (or primary, secondary, and tertiary outcomes). 2) Estimate the variability of each outcome based on prior evidence. 3) Identify the necessary sample size for the primary outcome based on power analysis. 4) Allow for a sufficient number of subjects in both arms for multiple subgroup or effect modifier analyses. Remember: The sample size does not only depend on the statistical precision you need but also on the variability you're inherently allowed to observe. Always consider the "intention-to-treat" principle and the lost-to-follow-up principle when planning for the number of subjects in your study. Tips Don't underestimate the size you need for early stopping for futility, and don't overestimate the statistical power you have due to the unknown variability you'll observe. Think about and include all the relevant subgroups and effect modifiers. Sample size calculations also depend on the number of comparisons you wish to make. If you are interested in several outcomes, include enough subjects to analyze those outcomes of interest appropriately - don't run the risk of inadvertently Type II error from underpowering the other outcomes. Don't over-categorize your treatment arms If possible, don't dichotomize. Don't forget to plan for follow up time. Consider drop-outs and treatment discontinuation when doing power calculation considerations. When doing an interim analysis, use a larger sample size to be conservative. Remember, even if you are not looking for superiority, you would need to show non-inferiority. Don't overestimate how long the intervention effect will last. Consider drop-outs, early discontinuation of treatment - always have a sufficient sample size to evaluate these important factors. Considering withdrawals, crossover, lactation, exclusions, interruptions, or changes in treatments along the course of the study. Consider 2 sided testing or multiple hypothesis testing. Always incorporate an a priori plan for multiplicity adjustments into your sample size calculations. Consider an increased sample size for multiple covariates if possible. Consider the fact that many trials don't complete. Don't plan for the worst case scenario - use an average or median scenario Don

Connect-Home Plus is a structured telehealth program, which is based on the original Connect-Home randomized trial demonstrating a 33% reduction in hospital readmission rate among older adults following hospital discharge.1 A prior study testing the Connect-Home Plus model among African-American and Latino Medicare beneficiaries with dementia found a statistically significant 54% reduction in readmission.2 Intervening via the telephone as well as in the skilled nursing facility was efficacious in both trials. In addition, a recent R15 funding proposal from our Research at the Intersections of Science & Design & Art (RIDSA) Team suggests that the telehealth portion of the intervention may reduce readmission risk even more so when delivered over video.3 If so, the intervention effect would be even greater than what has been reported previously without the cost and logistical difficulty of visiting the patient in their homes. 3 However, a feasibility, acceptability, and pilot test with the Connect-Home Plus approach shown in Figure 3 is needed to determine if it works as well as anticipated. 3 In addition, we do not know whether a single phone call, which delivers the full dose of the intervention, is as effective as more calls. The study described would provide crucial information.

model_response: The type of clinical trial used to generate evidence on the effectiveness of an intervention is a Clinical Trial of an Intervention. An observational study is conducted when researchers aim to describe a population's exposure to a factor of interest. For example, an observational study might assess the incidence of people who develop a particular cancer after using a certain medication. The goal of a case-control study is to determine if an exposure or factor of interest precedes the outcome of interest. To determine if the exposure increases or decreases the risk of the outcome, researchers conduct a cohort study and follow individuals over time to determine the association between the exposure and the outcome. Phase 1 clinical trials are the earliest stages where researchers test a new treatment in a small group of people who have the disease or condition that the medication is designed to treat. Phase 2 clinical trials test the drug or treatment in a larger group of people with the disease or condition. In Phase 3 clinical trials, the drug or treatment is given to large groups of people with the disease or condition, and effects are compared to similar groups receiving either a placebo (sugar pill) or another treatment. Phase 4 clinical trials are conducted to study the drug to learn more about its risks, benefits, and best use. They are done after the drug or treatment is approved by the FDA.

model_response:
A feasibility study helps establish the practicality of conducting the proposed trial, and is generally done before the initiation of the main trial. It determines the likelihood of the study being successful, identifies any potential problems, and provides important information for the subsequent study design, cost-effectiveness, and analysis. A pilot or feasibility study requires a smaller sample size than the full-scale trial and helps to confirm the intervention protocol, randomization process, study instrumentation, and data collection procedures. This information can then be used to minimize problems in the future study by addressing obstacles identified during the pilot study. 
Exploratory or pilot studies involve no formal hypotheses or research question, rather it allows the investigator to define an initial research population, identify study subjects, collect data with a study instrument, and test the research design before embarking on a larger study. These studies are characterized by small sample sizes, are time-consuming, and are generally qualitative, descriptive, or case series. Phase 1 studies are used to study drug safety in small numbers of healthy volunteers, whereas phase 2 studies explore the dosage, effects, and safety of a treatment under investigation in a small number of patients with the disease of interest. Phase 3 studies are the largest subset of clinical trials and are used to confirm safety and efficiency of the treatment under investigation in a large number of patients affected by the disease. Phase 4 studies occur after a treatment is marketed (post-approval), and are often used to assess the long-term benefits and/or side effects of a particular treatment.
